38645076.review:
[h1]赌上生命的纯爱！[/h1]
诚如前辈所言，这是一部非常好的GAL入坑作。

剧情方面，主线支线脉络分明，在没进入春线之前每个章节都会对应一个可攻略的角色，分别是椿姬，花音，水羽。给的选项也都清晰明了，在重大选择之前BGM几乎都会有变化，方便玩家选择喜欢的角色进行攻略。主线剧情讲述了“勇者”和她的随从们对抗“魔王”的故事，其中的trcik、叙诡对于普通玩家来说还是挺难猜到的，最后的高潮部分揭晓了全部真相，拨开云雾的感觉令人大呼过瘾，在此不多做赘述。值得称道的是，支线部分也都是精心设计过的，其余三位性格迥异的角色也都有着各自精彩的故事，因此推荐通关所有结局。

人物方面，不仅仅是主角的“勇者”团体和魔王，其他配角也不乏有精彩的表现，譬如椿姬幸福又乐天的的一家人，被作为”野兽“塑造的黑帮老大浅井权三，执着于复仇亲父的时田雪等等。其中给我印象最深的就是”野兽“浅井权三，”生者，生者，路化冰河。人生没有四季，唯有那，寒冬的荒野“这是他的信条，他的人生只有漫漫长的冬季，没人能真正解释他为何要帮养子挡枪，他一直教育主角要成为人，我想他的死就是对主角最后的教训吧。

音乐方面，大多数根据名曲改编的BGM并没有任何一首给我极深的印象。不过主线结局的”Close your eyes“非常动听，令人难忘。所以呢，一定要通关主线结局啊！

总结：《G线上的魔王》是一部非常适合萌新入坑的galgame，在这部作品里玩家可以充分体会到视觉小说的魅力，推荐给所有喜欢GALGAME的玩家。

I played this all the way in 2010? (I think). Maybe putting around 65-70 hours. Literally had no idea what a visual novel was before then. All I wanted was to have my Japanese filling for the rest of my life since I didn't really watch anime and I came across a few torrents. What a great mistake. I buy this today because back then I had no legal means of acquiring it and I have to thank the developers for hours of entertainment.

Visual novels are not short nor are they hard to get into. Although there are less lengthy ones, this VN is the perfect size for a decent plotline to engross you. In my very biased opinion, this is one of the best entry visual novels you'll ever read. However, I'd also recommend Katawa Shoujo and that one is free. If you are not very knowledgable about VNs - it's a sort of weird. But there's always a first for everything and keep your expectations low. That's what I'm trying keep this review about.

It's 2017 and there are an exceedingly amount of hours that can be used to read visual novels. Consider this one if you are starting out. Cheers!

P.S. [i]check out vndb.org and search up visual novel recommendations on Google if you want more. And if you want to avoid the bad feels, spoil yourself by reading good old text game guides.[/i] :)

36690828.review:
First things first: Buy the voiced version! Yes, it's more expensive, but without voices it just sucks.

G-Senjou no Maou or otherwise called Devil on G-String is a Mystery / Drama Visual Novel, with a bit of romance an does its job fairly well. It's thrilling and at times touching as well - which should be exactly what you want, right?

I won't go into detail of the synopsis (you can read that on the shop page), but I will say: G-Senjou no Maou has a rather interesting story, that takes a lot of unexpected turns throughout the chapters and also intentionally leads the reader to make the wrong conclusions. While the prologue isn't really that appealing, you should definitely at least give chapter 2 a chance because that's when the story really starts to build up. The only thing I didn't like about the story is that Harus route is the only one that concludes everything. It's possible to jump into each of main heroines chapters (with the story ending after that chapter) but if it's not Harus route, then apparently the events of Harus route don't happen in the other routes. This causes a lot of strings to be untied and takes the impact away. As such the story really only makes sense if you play Harus route.

Perhaps it's biggest strength are its characters. G-Senjou no Maou boasts a high number of well detailed characters, with a lot of depth and personality added to them. Each of the four heroines (Tsubaki, Kanon, Mizuha, Haru) has her own chapter, with Harus chapter being the true route and also the longest and (from the point of view of many) best chapter. Because of this, every heroine has a lot of screentime that builds up their personality, with other characters like Yuki, Gonzou and later "Maou", getting their screentime between the chapters as well. That overall gives G-Senjou no Maou a good cast with a lot of likeable characters, even if they are "evil". While some characters are merely stereotypes (Tsubaki -> naive, childhood friend, Kanon -> stepsister, Mizuha -> classic tsundere ...) they are at least detailled enough to differ from the rest. I also want to highlight a rather interesting motivation on Maous side for his actions, it's always nice to see something that isn't "ruling the world".

G-Senjou no Maou has a visually appealing art style, though the characters designs aren't really unique and more "generic". This isn't necessarily bad though and I don't think a more unique style would make the VN any better anyway. What really stands out though, are the soundtracks. Almost all soundtracks are remixes of a number of different classic music pieces (which include Bach, Orff and other well known composers). This makes G-Senjou no Maous OST rather remarkable and fits well into the story.

All in all, I don't think G-Senjou no Maou is a necessary "must-read", but if you're a fan of drama or mystery, then maybe you should give it a try. And if you're not entirely opposed to romance, then it's even better. I wouldn't call G-Senjou no Maou a "true masterpiece", but it's fairly enjoyable.

Points? I think anything from 8 to 10 is justified. Personally I would give 9/10.

36585642.review:
*SPOILER FREE REVIEW!*

I'll level with you - when I originally heard about G-Senjou No Maou, I wasn't sure if was for me.  While I like my fair share of crime and dark themes, the story of the son of a yakuza boss didn't 100% appeal to me, so I bypassed it.  However, as I continued to search around online for enjoyable visual novels that were different from the average high school romance theme, G-Senjou No Maou kept popping up on everyone's lists...  so I thought what the hell, let's give it a go.  GREAT DECISION.

This game is popular for good reason.  The visuals are nice, the soundtrack is interesting in that it's reimagined and often modernised versions of real classical pieces by famous composers (you'll understand where the whole 'g-string' thing comes in here...  it's not about underwear), and it has an overall polished feel to it.  What really got me hooked was the plotline, how it was paced and how it unfolded.  At first, I was doubting whether the style of plot it had would really ensnare me to play through to the end, but it really got under my skin because it was so well written.  The speech and perspective of the protagonist is very natural and easy to want to follow.  The characters are not 2D in the slightest, all very important and different from your average schoolkid in various ways - they've all had dark experiences, they all have secrets...  and it makes their actions, thoughts and potential motivations VERY interesting and compelling because each of them could have a massive positive or detrimental impact to the events of the story, should they choose to.  There's a big theme of moral integrity throughout, of what is wrong and right, how to view and treat people, whether it's worth it to fight to stay in the 'light', or whether it would be more satisfying to embrace darkness and become something people would fear...  it walks that delicate line between insanity and purity that people do face in real life.  Should I do what's right, or what's easy?  Should I turn against humanity because of my own pain, or should I invest my belief in the power of love?  There are big questions in this plot, big struggles, constant surprises and exciting possibilities that keep you playing.

There are four routes in this game, and each have their own good and bad endings.  One character holds the 'true route', and I'm not going to spoil anyone, but if you find out which one that is, I would highly recommend pursuing that route LAST, because it leads you to an ending that closes off a lot of possibilities that are explored in the other routes, and not only that, but if you play the other routes first, you will have a higher appreciation of the feelings of the characters in the true route ending.  It's vital to explore every route in this game because, as is wonderful about visual novels, each one changes the story and the actions of the protagonist so that new situations arise and the characters go through major experiences that would not be possible had you not gone down that route.  Since a lot of big things happen in this game, the course of events changes massively in some cases and it's interesting to see that plot difference once you've played them all.

As for the story itself, it's surprisingly compelling, mysterious, full of secrets that you long to uncover, and full of action; there's criminal activity, hostage situations, espionage, murder, even terrorism...  the story is very well paced and told in a way that makes you not want to rest until you discover the truth.  It's exciting and thrilling, but it's also balanced out with romance elements and the in and out trappings of daily school life, which only helps to make the story more interesting, as it's a cool juxtaposition; one minute you're having lunch on the rooftop and laughing at the guy with the crush on the teacher, the next, you're shooting a gun in the streets trying to stop someone from activating a bomb...  it's crazy in just the right way.  Again, I won't spoil, but the twist in the true route's ending regarding the identity of a certain person and what people have to go through in order to protect those they love and try to achieve the happiest future they can is really worth the effort you put into the game.  There was a detail right at the very end that made me cry because, like the protagonist, I'd resigned myself to the thought that a certain possibility was gone...  and suddenly there it was, like an impossible dream come true.  Very well done.  Also, they really know how to present a villain.  I still see that guys eyes in my mind and feel a little flicker of nervousness every time I do.  He was written so well that his CG alone began to make me uncomfortable.  You'll probably see what I mean once you play the game and learn his personality.  When he had that little smile on his face...  I felt like he could see me through the screen and had already plotted my demise before I'd had the chance to click anything.

I'd like to close off by saying that sometimes, you have to pay a certain price to acquire a visual novel of a certain caliber, but G-Senjou No Maou managed to surpass my expectations by displaying a level of sophistication and enjoyability that punched above its price bracket.  A lot of other visual novels that cost this much are definitely not as good.  It has a maturity and poise to it that makes the whole experience feel like a real thrill and very much worth it.  Like I said, I didn't think it was gonna be my thing, and it's now one of my favourite visual novels I've ever played.  If you like crime, drama, psychology and the duality of darkness and light within the human mind, this is definitely for you.  If you're not sure, hey, I wasn't either, but I'd still recommend it, cos it'll get you hooked before you know it!.

Very strong performance.  And also, once you play, you'll understand...  EIICHI, YOU'RE NEVER GONNA SLEEP WITH THAT FRICKING TEACHER, STOP BEING A STALKY PERVERT!  *Ahem* okay I'm done.  ^_^

36525959.review:
While I find the pricing model a bit curious (separating voice as extra) I thought it was worth it.
I'm usually one to play through more lighthearted fare, but this one kept my interest quite well with its setting and characters. Protagonist may not be the most likeable, but that's kind of the point. There's definitely a few parts that left me feeling satisfyingly tense and uneasy to go around.

The music is also a highlight, with some very memorable takes on various classical pieces.

Note that this version has CGs cropped to fit the new 16:9 aspect. I think it was a valid decision and most CGs didn't lose an unacceptable amount, but perhaps the ability to run in 4:3 like the original build would've been a nice option for those less worried about widescreen utilization.

All-in-all, this is one of those visual novels I would recommend to basically anyone, and as the h-scenes were not important to the plot of this story (outside of showing the amazing weirdness of Usami...), it's no real loss that this is an all-ages version. This might make it less embarrassing to recommend to people outside of the usual VN loop and its stigma for porn.

35908388.review:
Before you start with this VN, be prepared to invest for quite a bit - the initial hours would almost make you drop it. But [i]make no mistake[/i], this is an awesome VN worth investing in.

The Background scores are plenty and I'd recommend listening to them separately after the game. The characters are well designed and have distinct personalities. Kudos to [b]AKABEiSOFT[/b] on their incredible story writing. There are [spoiler]2 endings per character except Haru (who is the original route)[/spoiler].

Even after finishing the game, it was still in my mind for quite some days - the ending with Haru in particular. It almost made me cry while completing it. Apart from making the setting a thriller, mystery and a bit of drama - there are a couple of 4th wall breakers as well (which to be honest, was completely unexpected).

I nevery really write about the characters, but the main female lead [b]Usami Haru[/b] is awesome by all accounts. Funny, eccentric and has an extremely sharp mind. Kudos to whoever created her. To be honest, the others literally pale in comparison to her.

In short, Buy the game already and have a great time!

[i]The steam version is censored (obviously) and the missing scenes have no impact on the storyline. However, this VN is too good and so I'm gonna see if I can get the uncensored one [/i]

There are 3 side routes which diverge from the "one true ending".  Actually, nothing in the one true ending seems to happen  in the other side routes.

The 3 other routes are mostly fluff.  (Mostly) sweet tiny romance stories about three of the other characters that are there along your story, two being school friends, and one being your step-sister.  However, it's important to play them at least once, and you'll know why once you finish the main route.

I have one and only one warning.  This game has been perfectly made.  There are quite literally no drawbacks.  You could say that the long dialogue is a "drawback", but every bit of dialogue in the game is important, so if you're there for the story, it won't matter.

The warning is that you will think about the game.  You'll question the way you think.  With the ending that it has, you will question your sense of justice and your sense of right and wrong, and you'll probably stick with this question: "Was it really fair?"

G-Senjou no Maou has [b] the most bittersweet endings in any story I have ever read or seen. [/b]  Whether it be anime, other visual novels, manga, light novels, novels, chapter books, biographies; you name it, it won't outdo this.

Granted, that's just what I've seen, though I've gone through many stories.  Even all that said, G-Senjou no Maou has, hands down, the most bittersweet ending that I have ever witnessed, and I couldn't hold back tears at all.  Tears and anger at the unjustice of it.

I won't spoil much.  In fact, I don't think any of this has spoiled anything of the story, but you're free to let your mind wander.

My real, true warning is that if you can't handle, in your current mental state, a story that will tug your heartstrings like a puppeteer playing cruelly with its least favourite puppet, then don't start now.  Wait until you're better.  Wait until you have someone to talk about the ending to and hold.  You'll need that someone.  [b] Trust me. [/b]

33687168.review:
Let me preface this by stating that it actually took me picking up the VN once, dropping it, then forcing my way through about half of the story before I was firmly hooked.  I'm glad I listened to the raving endorsements of my fellow VN-loving friends and didn't give up a second time, as pushing through to the meat of the narrative was well worth it.  I can't remember the last time a VN (or book for that matter) had me up until the wee hours of the night unable to pull myself away from the intrigue.  The Devil on G-String is a compelling crime drama that had me second guessing everything I thought I knew for almost its entire length before smacking me with a gut-wrenching finale that stuck with me long after I was done.  
 
It's difficult to offer a short description of the story without giving anything away, but I'll try.  Our protagonist is Kyousuke Azai, a young man living a dual life of high school student in the day and yakuza underling at night.  Kyousuke isn't your regular yakuza thug, however.  Adopted by one of the organization's most ruthless leaders, he's stuck in the precarious position of paying off old family debts while trying to drag himself out from under his foster father's abusive thumb.  When an awkward young woman transfers to his high school class, life spirals out of control as he's dragged into the vendetta between Usami Haru and the mysterious criminal mastermind named Maou.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1083518166  
That little synopsis doesn't even scratch the surface of the story as the plot twists and turns in ways that will have you dizzy before long.  Kidnap, murder, betrayal, deceit, revenge - there are very few atrocities not touched upon, and the writers bring it all to life with fast-paced action, vivid imagery, and lively banter between the characters.  Even the narration is excellently paced with a rhythm that ebbs and flows with the action.  Rich descriptions and familiar cultural references that don't feel ham-fisted leave little question in my mind that the translators did one hell of a job localizing this brilliant piece of fiction.  

Unfortunately, the side routes are where the excellence falters.  Serving as little more than fluff-filled diversions from the main plot, they slow down the narrative and prevent the reader from getting to the meat of the story for far too long.  Yes, they add some back story to Kyousuke, but it's not enough to make the amount of time you'll spend reading through them worth it.  When I do read it again (which I indeed will at some point), I'll be skipping them entirely.   

The overall presentation is phenomenal with gorgeous artwork and so many CGs I felt like I was watching a movie at times.  The voice overs are also extremely well done, and I'd suggest picking up the voice pack if you happen to have the extra dollars (though the story is good enough to hold its own without them).  I only wished the soundtrack was a little more memorable.  I know that sounds odd considering it's comprised entirely of arrangements of classical masterpieces, but I feel like the sound quality of the instrumentation used just doesn't do them justice.  At least they weren't disruptive to the story at all.   

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1083517450
I really wish I could delve further into explaining just why you NEED to read this, but doing so would only ruin the experience.  So I will leave you with this: If you enjoy well-written thrillers that will have you on the edge of your seat one moment and holding back tears the next, then you need to read The Devil on G-String.  It really is one of the best visual novels I've read in quite some time.  It's disappointing that relatively few people have read it, as it truly is an underrated gem that needs to be appreciated.

33598161.review:
Do you like crime stories? Mysteries with mountains upon mountains of plot twists? How about a soundtrack that is inherently tied to the story? Would you like to have to think, have your heart tramped, and (repeatedly) get your mind blown? 

If you answered "yes" to any of the above, buy The Devil on G-String now. Heck, buy it at full price. It's worth it. Emphasis on the mountains of plot twists - this story lives to catch you off-guard with logic games.

The story is set up pretty linearly, with opportunities to branch off into other character routes before pursuing the true ending (no branching). [b]For all that is good and holy, save the true ending for last.[/b] You can delve deeper into different characters' situations in the side branches, leading to a bigger understanding (and impact) of the true ending. 

There is something wonderful to experience here. I beg that you experience it as well.

32166921.review:
如果将来需要向他人推荐Galgame，那么此作必然在名单之中。于我而言，最为看重的是GAL的剧情和音乐，而此作在这两个方面都可称之为神作，尽管存在一些剧情bug。下述评价可能涉及剧透，请斟酌后再行阅读。

在具体评价之前，只想吐槽一句，为什么到最后会不知道女儿的名字啊，逼死强迫症系列！ [spoiler]个人看法：鲛岛清美。寓意大概是斩断复仇的锁链，结束两代人的纷争吧~[/spoiler]

[b]剧情：9.5/10[/b]
    《G弦上的魔王》只是披着日常系的外衣，实则一部精彩绝伦、动人心魄的悬疑推理剧，创意，就是其剧情最大的资本，已然超越大多数GAL。整部作品以女主宇佐美春为复仇而与魔王斗智斗勇为主线，穿插校园生活等日常。每一章都会出现魔王所精心谋划的犯罪，而春则需要凭借自己的过人才智与魔王过招，剧情曲折多变，让人永远琢磨不透下一秒会发生什么。而每当春在章尾一步一步推理出魔王的犯罪手法时，都会让人惊叹魔王高超的犯罪手法和春缜密的逻辑推理能力，仿佛在春身上看到了福尔摩斯的影子。
      而进入第五章和终章（春线）后，剧情变得更加精彩，甚至完全盖过了前四章的光辉。剧情在这里更是多次反转，直到最后才让人放下紧张忐忑的心情。除了与魔王的最终斗争之外，此段剧情的爆发点还在于人物的情感，尤其是男女主角之间的爱情，结尾的安排出乎意料却又是情理之中，第一次遇见这种套路的人都会被深深折服。
       剧情硬伤也不是没有，例如在主线和支线中魔王的身份就完全不同，尽管有很多解释，但终究是有bug存在的；其次，支线给人的感觉是较为平淡和脱线的，男主存在感也较低。

[b]音乐：10/10[/b]
       整部游戏共有67首曲子，大部分都是有寓意地取材古典，十分用心。而游戏中的BGM几乎都是改变自古典音乐（少数几首改编自主题曲），包括贯穿整部游戏的《G弦上的咏叹调》和《魔王》等名曲，也不乏《月光》《卡农》《欢乐颂》这些耳熟能详的曲子，使得BGM怒刷一波存在感。光有名曲改编自然不够，其与剧情的配合才是令人赞叹，瞬间将人带入到游戏氛围之中，但偶尔会使人沉浸在音乐之中而忽视了剧情。
       67首曲子中也有好几首Vocal，片头曲《Answer》十分燃，很容易地就把人带入到高潮迭起的剧情之中；而《Close your eyes》及其改编曲则是催泪风格，游戏中曾多次出现，但还是在终章中最催人泪下的高潮部分赚够了一番眼泪。

[b]人设：9/10[/b]
整部游戏的人设都十分新颖，大概是由于题材的原因。
       男主浅井京介是一个命运多舛，最终沦为黑帮老大养子[spoiler]实为家畜[/spoiler]的腹黑角色，但其个人的能力也十分出众，出色地权衡着生活与工作。时刻不忘自己的母亲，想着尽早还清欠款与母亲团聚；在与魔王的斗争中多次救出女主，并最终承担所有罪过。这些都塑造出一个有血有肉、极具人格魅力的男主角色，与多数稀里糊涂却拥有主角光环的GAL男主形成巨大反差。
       女主宇佐美春初次登场时给人的印象就是完全脱线，但是随着其一次又一次与魔王的交锋，春展现出了自身极高的智商和惊人沉着。而男女主之间的感情戏也十分出彩，整整18年，每一次的相聚似乎都意味着残忍的别离，但女主始终没有放弃，一心一意爱着男主，并因他而更加坚定于自己的小提琴家梦想，这样执着坚毅的女票，该去哪里找呢？
       魔王这一角色的塑造十分成功，成功到几乎没人会吐槽这部游戏的男女比例~作为游戏的中心人物之一，魔王拥有远超宇佐美春的智商和君子报仇，十年不晚的决心毅力。尽管魔王实施了众多犯罪，甚至最终将中心街演变成地狱，但仇恨他的玩家并不多，因为在深入了解其背景之后，魔王的做法都有着合理之处，这也是魔王的人格魅力所在吧。
      ……

总之，《G弦上的魔王》是一部入坑神作，值得品味。

This game made me started listening to classical music, and I love both this game and the music so much.
- G-senjou no Maou splits to several chapters, and each one can uniquely lead to alternative ending of the 4 heroines which I've never seen this kind of system before (regularly they go mainly with a main routes and after that seperate the route to heroines' endings or true ending or so)
- The most captivated part for me is the ost which is WELL arranged from classical music (canon, fur elise, amazing grace, etc.) and it shows on the screen which song is currently playing which later made me a breakthrough to classical music.
- Theme of this VN is mind-gaming. Main characters clash each other not with bare-hand but brain-using which is freaking COOL and hard to stop playing. Plot and twists in the story made me think it is more than worth buying this game.
- Unfortunately I found 2 things which are considered the drawbacks of this game. Firstly, it focuses too much on the route of the main heroine (Usami Haru) and makes the others too short in length. Even though those routes are high quality and really touch me, I think it would be more sentimental if I can spend more time with the girls.
- Secondly, this game shows the best of psycological fight and plot twists that I have ever seen, but unfortunately at the very last chapters the fascination of unpredictable plot is suddenly dropped and overcome by melodrama and easy-guessing plot procedure. I'm not hate a melodrama plot, the true ending is even one of the best ending that I almost cry, but the game cannot make my heart beating like the very first chapters.

- To conclue, everyone should play this visual novel, honestly. It contents many feeling and bring you toward 'devil' which live in the deepest part of everyone's mind like the G-string, the biggest string and the lowest sound of the violin.

31111635.review:
I REALLY enjoyed it. 

I would recommend to go into the experience of reading this visual novel completely blind. As a reader you are checking reviews to see whether or not there is anything in particular that may be problematic with the game or to help sway your opinion to buy the game and read it. And there is no problem with doing this. This review will accommodate this purchase methodology.

Generally checking reviews is the safest way to go about making a purchase. But, in this particular case researching too much will have the opposite effect and ruin the experience of reading the story. There is a difference between reading with background info and with minimum information known. The latter is the best way to enjoy this game, hence no breakdown of the story. [i]However[/i], this isn't to say there aren't problems with the product nor will I exclude some information on the structure of the game and discuss presentation tidbits. I will go in order of structure, problems, and then presentation, following a conclusion.

[h1]Structure:[/h1] 
There are four routes you can go through. In terms of setup there is a prologue, 5 chapters and an epilogue. A route coincides with a chapter, and each route, except the "true" route, has a possible bad ending. The ending you receive is influenced by the decisions you make while playing. In total it took me approximately 18 hours to read, including every route and ending.


[h1]Problems:[/h1] 
In my 18 hours of playing there were a few notable issues present. Sometimes the skip text button would not work properly and skip all text that was read before; however this was mainly present in the beginning, but disappeared later after I switched the option from "All" to "text read". One other issue the game suffered from was crashing when accessing Steam overlay. As long as I did not access Steam overlay while playing there were no crashing problems, and in most cases it was rectified through regular saving. Taking screenshots was sometimes a hit or miss too. Sometimes the overlay feature wouldn't work and would require a quick restart to work properly. Finally there were a few issues in translation. Not many were present, but some stuck out and were fairly noticeable in the later half of the game.

It is also worth noting that there are some disputes about the Steam version being censored. However, it did not take away from the experience. 


[h1]Presentation: [/h1]
The game's art and music are terrific, in my opinion. You can get a strong sense of what is going on throughout the game using the imagery provided. *I did not buy the voice edition; and would not mind updating my review in the future to accommodate it when I do; however, for the moment it will not touch on that specific.* In terms of UI it is simple and straight-forward with no navigation issues. There are also more than enough save slots to accommodate regular saving and multiple playthroughs. Lastly, most tracks are based off of pieces of classical music. The original, non-classical, scores made for this visual novel complimented the classical renditions well. In the top right-hand corner when a new track begins the classical score is noted as well, providing it has one.


[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
In closing, this game was a phenomenal experience. The structure is fairly standard with a decently long read time, there are some technical issues in this version of the game and other issues such as censorship; however, the presentation of the visual novel is will done. The art and music go together well and by all means is a very story rich experience. 

I would recommend this product.

28829054.review:
I've already read the original VN before I purchased the Steam version. The main difference is that they cut the adult content and edited some CGs and that's pretty much it.

G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String is definitely one of the best Visuals Novels available on Steam, one of my favourites as well.

[h1]The Good Stuff[/h1]
The story is superb, this VN is all about crimes in the underworld. Kidnapping, murder, genocides, etc. and they did a very good job with it so it's really hard for you to actually get bored with it. The intro "Maou vs Haru" is one of my favourite scenes in the game.

Soundtracks are great. I'm actually quite surprised knowing how many soundtracks in this game that are actually good. Try to listen to [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jfthFelJnsk]"The Moment of Truth/Shiyuu"[/url] and you'll understand why, Tiko-μ is such a top tier music arranger.

Artworks? Not much to say here, the game was first released back in 2008 so the it looks a bit dated compared to recent VNs. Regardless, they're still pretty nice to look at.

[h1]The uhh... not so good stuff, opinion-ish[/h1]
Side routes. I did say that the story is amazing and indeed they are, but that is because I was talking about the "True Route" of the game. Now, I'm not saying that their routes are bad, I actually like them, I just want to say that their routes is not that amazing when you compare them to the "True Route".

What else? One thing that I didn't really like was the Chapter 4 when [spoiler]Tokita is revealed to be the 'Maou' childrens. I don't know, it came out of nowhere so it felt forced considering she doesn't have that much screentime compare to everyone. In the end, I could not sympathize about her for the rest of the game.[/spoiler]
Yeah, probably it's just me being nitpicky and all but eh, I need to at least get this thing off from my chest.

In conclusion, I highly recommend this VN. If you are actually new to the VN genre, this one is a good start. I guarantee you.

P.S If possible, try to follow the game based on the walkthrough so you can actually appreciate the side routes and makes the ending even better.

27711678.review:
The Devil on G-String is the game which introduced me to the Visual Novel genre, 
thanks to this game that I was able to see the light !
you might ask what light ? well I'll try to explain myself cause my "light" and your "light" is a bit different.
First of all I need to admit about something, I'm an Otaku or in other words "geek" by how the society calls us in Japan
( while I do not see myself as one ), 
my hobbies are reading, playing video games, and watching anime.
But I never had the pleasure to do all those three at the same time...
its either playing video games or reading or watching anime. 
While you can find some video games based on anime or mangas on those same anime or video games about books ( Tom Clancy's anyone ? ) but never all those three together. 
Then came TellTale with an amazing idea taking a famous comic book series as well as the popular Tv series "The Walking Dead" and made from it a game which combines all the three of my hobbies 
( reading, playing, and getting inside the "comic" world ). But I'm more into anime\manga than comics.
That's when I found out about "The Devil on G-String" same idea as TellTale's walking dead game, which also does what I was looking for. 

Now what do you expect from this game ? 
First of all there are alot of words, it should take about 30-50 hours of reading to finish this game.
Why should you read it ? or "play" thorugh it ? 
well its really simple, if you are the same as me then go ahead and try it, and you should cause you won't regret it.
Unlike the Telltale's game this game "choices" really matter, this game shows us 7 different endings ( as far as I know )
with 3 routes non cannon ( its like a side story ), with one main route ( the best one ).
The idea is you have 4 different girls and you pick one who you want to end with ( japan ladies and gentelmen ).
Each and every character has a unique personality ( some of them are cliche anime personality ),
But all of them have a story to tell, a story that will unfold as you progress and there will be some consequences for your actions ( your choices ) as to what to do or what to say.
The main protagonist isn't really a "hero" he is a human being with flaws, he isn't some kind of saviour or saint.
You might even hate him for his actions at the beggining ( he will do evil acts if neccesary if YOU chose to ).
I won't tell anything about the storyline cause as a matter of a fact its one of the best storytelling I have ever read in my entire life ( better than most books that I read ). 
I might add that this game made me shed tears at some points in the story.
Therefore you should play it ( I played first time with the pirated version and because I enjoyed it so much I had to buy it on steam when it came out, which I waited to do so for 2 years ).

TL:DR
Buy it 
Have patience,
Enjoy it and cry alot.

G-senjou no Maou is a masterpiece. I want to start by saying that i've played many visual novels, for example Rewrite, Steins;Gate and Katawa shoujo. G-senjou no Maou is fast phased if we compare it to regular visual novel, it has around 30 hours of gameplay although the game could easily be 40 hours or more. The fast phasing keeps you on the edge of your seat the entire time. 

Visuals:

The visuals were stunning, very beautiful artwork. 

Sound:

Soundtrack was so good my ears had an eargasm, voice acting was also very good and it made certain scenes stronger so i would definitely recommend buying the voice pack DLC.

Story:

Story was very well built overall, i feel like every route could have been given a bit more follow up but thats just my opinion. 

Characters: 

Every character has its own route, although the game doesn't use the regular route system where you have a different story for every character. The game uses a system where you ultimately have one single storyline. 

Enjoyment:

Had fun, cried, laughed, cried laughing.

Overall:

10/10 for every aspect, this is definitely the best visual novel i have ever played and it will be REALLY hard to top this one.

This must be one of best visual novels on steam and it certainly made it between my favorites.

25467860.review:
One of the best Visual Novels out there.

Inteligent thriller that keeps you invested from very begining to the very end and has quite a bit of mystery to unravel along with the story progression - with a really well executed twists :)
Characters are well presented with diverse personalities fitting for the setting.

Godly soundtrack - you can never go wrong with classical music motifs and I keep listening to it quite often after finishing the novel.

Beautiful, detailed artwork and a lot of CGs to see, all in HD, are an another strong point.

No problems with censorship - my friend, who recommended me this title, was worried about losing the "spirit" of the story, but the only thing missing from the non-steam version are the "adult bits", while all the R-rated stuff is still there untouched.

Voices - definitely worth the extra price - they enrich the experience tremendously, and considering the lenght of the story (about 60 hours for me), it is not overpriced anyway.

Interface itself is nice and clean, with aditional features of showing you what music now started playing and who was the original composer, and also changing colors of each character text individually - quite interesting and unique.

Overall I would definitely recommend this title, as it should appeal to most people. For me it is within top 3 best novels I have played.

Die Geschichte ist spannend geschrieben mit einigen guten Story-Twists, welche stellenweise erahnt werden können. So macht es Spass, ein wenig mitzurätseln. Dennoch verbleiben einige Plot holes, was ich persönlich aber nicht so schlimm fand.
Die "Normale" Geschichte und True Ending Route waren leider die einzigen, die wirklich Überzeugen könnten(und auch bis zur letzten Minute fesselten). Die anderen 3 Romanzen kommen leider nicht über gewöhnliches Mittelmass hinaus und sind sehr stark abhängig, ob man das Entprechende Mädchen auch sympathisch findet. Im Gegensatz zu Grisaia sind diese nicht einmal richtig relevant zur Hauptgeschichte und füllen das Becken mit diversen Plot holes.

Mir persönlich gefiel der Hauptcharakter nicht, da er in meinen Augen einfach ein Ar***loch ist. Dennoch besitzt er Qualitäten, die ihn dennoch sympathisch machen können

Well wow its just outstanding at times how in depth and well thought out these VNs are. 

So in this VN you are a business minded kid that has to pay off the debt of his father that was forced into a bad situation by the Yakuza meaning 100million yen debt, in the mean time a women that is a hairy mess enters the stage searching for an entity by the name of Maou which is japanese for devil. Well Maou is antagonist of this story, he has a noble goal but he is willing to go very far to achieve those goals, he will destroy anything and everything his path to achieve his goals. 

Watch as the protagonists have their lives systematically destroyed as Maou constantly fights in order to get an advantage over his opponents and yes there are twists there are plot twists that you will not see even if it stares right at you. 

Your very motives, morals and judgement will be tested bridging the gap betweenr right and wrong, the grey areas of laws and the raw brutality of extremists on sides of violence, terrorism and hope. 

This is 30+ hours worth of pure edge of the seat material. If you love reading, battles between pure geniuses and an a complex story then this is for you. I cannot recommend it enough.

[h1]Скучное начало, скучные второстепенные руты и отменный главный рут - это всё The Devil on G-String.[/h1] Здесь вы увидите детективную 30-50ч. историю о противостоянии двух очень колоритных и гениальных персонажей Хару Усами и Мау(the Devil), со множеством сильных сюжетных поворотов от которых отходишь по несколько дней (серьезно, преугадать их сложно), остальные персонажи тоже хороши, но выделяются именно эти двое. И всё это под несколько десятков классических музыкальных произведений (довольно оригинально, любители классики точно оценят), красивых CG и необычную атмосферу криминальной Японии. Сам сюжет очень хорошо проработан и не смотря на скучноватое начало, по мере развития становится действительно интересно, раскрываются мотивы главных героев и антагониста, а в конце уже невозможно оторваться от всей его сложности и гениальности.
Из минусов отметил бы: выразены h-сцены, малое взаимодействие (выборов немного, поэтому можно сказать, что она почти кинетическая; некоторые не посчитают это минусом), неинтересные второстепенные руты и присутствие бесячих персонажей (понять логику Цубаки крайне тяжело, она просто тупая; не в обиду её фанатам). Английский здесь не очень простой да и текста много, поэтому у некоторых могут возникнуть с ним трудности.
[h1]В итого мы получаем очень хорошую новеллу (+высокий рейтинг на VNDB) за приемлемую цену, поэтому смело рекомендую к приобретению.[/h1]

If you hate stories with incompetent villains and bumbling heroes, this VN is for you. G-senjou no Maou is a thrilling back-and-forth mind game between two adversaries: Haru, a transfer student with uncanny intuition, and 'Maou', a criminal mastermind and magnificent bastard to the nth degree. 24317161.review:
I wonder how many people pass up this game based on misunderstanding the title? I hate to admit it, but I used to be one of those people, but no longer.

With that said, let's start with the title: The Devil on G-String. 

The game is essentially about a battle of wits between a "hero" and a "devil," called "maou" in the game, with a pleasing reliance on classical music to set up things. Thus, the "G-String" refers to a violin string, not underwear. Most of the soundtrack is comprised of songs built on classical music, and a violinist and a fan of classical music make up two of the core characters. 

While you don't need to have any real knowledge of music going in, chances are you'll recognize some of the music, which is a nice touch. The game's arrangement of the songs gives them a unique flair that fits very well with the game's mood and setting, and one of the tracks in particular is probably one of my favorite visual novel tracks ever now. 

As for the story, well, it goes like this. You've got the adopted son of a yakuza boss running around doing shady-but-not-quite-illegal business for his adopted father's company in order to pay off a massive debt he owes. He lives for money. There's political intrigue, comedy, violence, drama, and even romance galore to be had here. 

Then this "Maou" character comes into the picture, followed by a girl calling herself "Hero" that's hot on his tail, and starts stirring up trouble, all while your protagonist tries to keep up his double life and get rich. He's an open sleazeball, which in a way, is somewhat refreshing compared to other protagonists.

The story is pretty solid, though you might find yourself let down with certain aspects of it towards the end. It's not the longest visual novel in the world, but it's well written and entertaining enough that if you're drawn in, it should keep you sufficiently entertained for more than a while. Even longer than me if you don't skip read text or use saves to reload from choice spots.

As I mentioned before, the soundtrack is also really nice, and despite being built on classical music, even if you're not a fan, you should not find yourself bored with the tracks this game has in its arsenal. The art style is also pretty pleasing to the eyes, and the amount of CGs they managed for this isn't too bad either, all things considered.

One issue that popped up a few times for me, however, was the game's localization. Besides for a few typos here and there, it is just somewhat bizarre to have situations where characters are both using honorifics and "onii-chan" as well as things like "Babe" and "Baby" for their partners, among other... interesting choices. Once you get used to it, if you can get used to it, it's enjoyable in its own way, but it's jarring.

On the other hand, while I personally found this to be a good example that fading to black works fine in a game that originally had sexual content in it, I'm sure there are people who disagree, so for what it's worth, I'll mention that yes, this version of the game is missing it. 

All things considered, though the game does suffer from some focus issues involving its heroines, which I'll mention below, I'd say that while it may not be a masterpiece, it's definitely worth a read if you enjoy visual novels. 

**MINOR SPOILERS FOLLOW**

Positives aside (and there are many positives here), one point of contention I do have with the game is its focus. 

In chapters two through four, the player is introduced to scenarios that involve three different heroines, and they are given the option to branch off to different routes focusing on the other heroines. At this point, the player can enter the route and pursue the heroine romantically (or to get a bad end) or keep on with the main story.

One of the issues I found was that, justified well or shakily, the game tended to write off the other heroines as soon as their chapter in the main scenario ended. In two of the three cases, the other heroines weren't even particularly present in the story to begin with, and in one of those cases still, their personal route just left a lot to be desired. All in all, it leaves a bit of a poor aftertaste and a desire for more for those characters.

Then, when it finally comes time for the main heroine, another focus-related problem arises - the game then has to switch gears from prioritizing her as part of the plot to a love interest, and at times, I'm not sure it handled that balancing as well as it could have. The conclusion is definitely worth it all when everything is said and done, though, but the road getting there (in terms of the "heroine" part of her arc) was definitely a little more bumpy compared to the first two routes in the game.

But would I still recommend the game despite all this? Absolutely.

24309960.review:
[h1]——献给宇佐美春与浅井京介，愿他们仍然过着平安而正常的生活。	[/h1]

早在这部游戏登录steam的时候就该把评测写了的（预购要40刀啊喂，一个月之后国区上线瞬间缩水一大半啊！），但是当你太喜欢一个什么的时候反而会不知道说什么好，再加上我作死想全英文通三周目，所以就顺利的拖到了最后一天···

欸？为什么今天（7月14日）是最后一天？因为现在登录steam的日式文字冒险游戏/视觉小说/Galgame越来越多了啦！就在今天早些时候我刚发现minori的sppl无声无息的更新了商店页面（30日发售，大家快去买让minori把2众筹出来），与此同时海猫鸣泣之时已经卖了一波，巴德尔天空即将上市，而明天（15日）“世界上最伟大的”Muv-Luv就要发售了——

——到了明天，我就再也不敢拍着胸脯说“G弦上的魔王是steam上最优秀的Galgame”了。

而趁今天还来的及，我要抓紧机会再说一遍——“G弦上的魔王是steam上最优秀的Galgame！”或者至少，它是steam 上最优秀而“正统”的一个。

好了，enough said。这部游戏已经出品九年了，无数人描写过自己怎么被感动，发掘点评人物和剧情，以及举着资源四处安利，大家一搜索肯定俯拾皆是，我就直接评分吧。

G弦上的魔王 出品公司：AKBSoft

[b]系统：A+ 	[/b]
显而易见，比起旧版本系统全部重制过了。UI简洁易用，优化顺滑流畅。

[b]剧情：S [/b] 
一反绝大多数同类游戏白开水一样的日常，剧情几乎全程高能，充满燃点、笑点和泪点，后半部分高潮迭起、一波三折，有的时候角色打破第四堵墙说出些神奇的反讽台词又总能令人忍俊不禁。同样一反常态的是，游戏中毫不避讳的刻画现实社会中的黑暗面，全程在社会的灰色地带中游走，虽然仍有疏漏之处，但其真实感和代入感出类拔萃。
剧情在许多层面上虽然还算不上发人深省，但至少具备一定的深度和哲理性。同时这是一部真正的完整长篇视觉小说，想要全部通读至少需要30~40小时时间。
值得注意的是，英文翻译非常通顺优美，阅读感受超出预期。全年龄版除了本来就可有可无的h部分以外对剧情毫无影响。

[b]角色：S[/b]
故事中有四位性格鲜明的主要女性角色，通过选择决定路线。值得注意的是，除了主线之外其他三位女性角色的线路都有Bad End存在，因此全游戏共有七个结局。全篇分为五章，除了第一章序章以外每一章都有一位女主角，如果你选择了某一章的女主角的话将会直接进入个人线而错过之后的主线（然后春会过来和你说一堆伤感的话），建议在选项过程中多加存档，以免错过重要节点。当然了，一定不要错过最为精彩、跌宕起伏的主线（“感谢你排除万难终于选择了我！”）。
就我个人而言，最喜欢水羽（水羽线的后日谈剧情虽然短小，但角色的转变太惹人喜爱啦），其次是女主春。

[b]画面：B+[/b]
本游戏的画面虽然不算过时，但毕竟人设和立绘都有些年头了，而且画风也不是以追求美感为主要目的的类型。女主更是···格外有特点（长发及腰+夹克衫私服什么的），因此算不上特别优秀。不过值得欣慰的是全游戏所有背景立绘CG都经过了高清重制，分辨率上有了极大提升。

[b]CV：A+[/b]
Steam上多数视觉小说都没有CV的事实极大提升了这里CV的存在感···当然演出本身也是十分出色的。天知道我多少次翻来覆去回放宇佐美同学的某几句话（？）。当然你会注意到语音包和游戏本体是分开卖的···绝对不要错过！她的声优瑞泽溪还配过《美好的每一天》里的水上由歧喔！

[b]音乐：S+[/b]
除了精心创作的几首主题曲（Answer、Close your eyes和雪之羽，时之风）及其变体以外，所有的配乐全部都由经典古典乐改编。事实上从名字和简介中也可轻松获知，古典乐在本作中也有着不小的象征意义。这也是游戏最大的特色之一。而且片尾插入曲超级好听和应景的。

[b]总评：S[/b]
多年之后再回头看，G弦上的魔王大概算不上真正意义上的“伟大”作品，但它是一个以足够长度的篇幅讲述了一段（几段？）足够精彩的悬疑·爱情故事的良作，在拥有优秀脚本、高制作水准与完成度的前提下具有属于自己的特色（以业界的一般水平能做到这点已经很难得了···）。纵观整个市场，它比不上那些批评空间90分+的里程碑式作品（muv和白色相簿）或者另一些话题性/艺术性/哲理性足够强的精彩作品（Fate、EF或者美好的每一天）。但自他于去年推出之时至今，steam上有的要不然是独立作品、中短篇作品（eden），要不然是未完全体作品（灰色系列和当时的寒蝉），G弦上的魔王与之相比优势十分明显。而即使是现在它也绝对值得一玩——对于类型游戏爱好者来说绝对不该错过。

推荐给所有有情怀的、或者单纯想要读个好故事的玩家与视觉小说读者。

The G-string in the name of the title means The G-String of a Violin.. the violin & the g-string have strong emotional value in this story.. 

Unlike many other visual novels this visual novel has no fantasy or erotica theme. No erotic fanservice anywhere & No magical girl stuff. its a realistic story

Anything I say will be a spoiler. Read this visual novel without any prior knowledge for best expierience. Its a mature & deep story about Rivalry & Revenge. Initially I put this on my wishlist merely for the artwork and potential that it had for storyline value. So when it came up under the Summer Sale, I spent for the voiceless version, as I wasn't too preoccupied and just wanted to take some things off my list. To be fair, my expectations weren't very high and the beginnings of the story seemed to mold into the impressions that I had that this would be a pretty art, bumbling characters tale...

Except that it wasn't. Certainly there was varied tropes within the characters, and comedic byplay that was so over the top that it was useless even as a gag. However, the storyline that evolved, especially as you played through the entirety of the story, served to flesh out each of the characters in the main line to some degree and definitely served to dish up the main course of the Devil inside of Man. Je n'ai pas fais beaucoup de Visual Novels, mais je n'ai pas de doute à dire ces mots : 

G-senjou no Maou est un chef d'oeuvre.
Il est dur d'en parler sans trop en spoiler mais en gros, attendez vous à un personnage des plus charismatiques avec des plans farfelus (Maou !!!), des personnages très attachants (sauf Eiichi. Il sert à rien), un VN rempli de plot twists, le dernier chapitre rempli d'action, et cette ending, cette fin, qui est vraiment extraordinaire et tout simplement une des meilleurs fins de toutes les oeuvres que j'ai lu/joué/regardé.
Ca peut paraître peu important mais l'OST du jeu est tout bonnement excellente, de la musique classique, et une musique qui nous fait chialer à la fin, 

Son seuls défaut est le manque des scènes H sur cette version Steam (normal, et toujours pas de patch/mod à ce jour), même si, pour les avoir lu dans le jeu original, n'ont rien de fou, et que le jeu en général est mal équilibré : le jeu devient vraiment "fou" seulement à la fin et des personnes peuvent drop G-senjou no Maou. Personnellement, je n'ai pas droppé mais j'ai mis un bon mois à tout lire (30h de lecture il me semble), mais le dernier chapitre + ending, je l'ai lu d'un traite.

Les fins alternatives sont bien écrites mais si vous devez faire qu'une seule fin par manque de temps et bien faites que la fin classique, qui est la meilleure de toute façon.

En bref, G-senjou no Maou est un des meilleurs VN disponibles sur Steam. Si vous n'avez jamais lu de VN je vous recommande fortement de commencer par celui-ci.

Code Geass

21957110.review:
[h1] G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String Review [/h1]

[b] Story [/b]

The Devil on G-String has an engaging story. It does take until the end of Chapter 1 to do so though. Also, the main story gets more and more intense per chapter too. The writing is excellent, but has some vulgarity and many pop culture references. In the end, the story made me feel all kinds of emotions. 

Rating: 8.5/10

[b] Graphics [/b]

All I can say is that the graphics look nice. The character art, backgrounds, and UI have nice synergy.

Rating: 9.5/10

[b] Music and Sound [/b]

Most of the music was an interesting rendition of classical music. The music still managed to be creative enough in its own way though. I could feel the intensity and emotion of each song. The sound effects are pretty average, but get the job done just fine. Both the music and sound made reading the text more immersive.

Rating: 9/10

[b] Characters [/b]

Each of the characters have a distinct personality and text color. They range from having a dark past to an innocent childhood. Throughout the story, you can see the characters developing themselves and their relationships. I felt empathy, sympathy, happiness, anger, sadness, etc. towards the characters. Not too many character tropes, like a tsundere, are used either.

Rating: 10/10

[b] Gameplay and Miscellanous [/b]

The gameplay is very simple and works well. Saving and Loading works well (especially with 150 save slots plus the quick save file). I found no bugs in the game either. 

Rating: 10/10

[b] Overall Score: [/b] 47/50

Well, after 16 hours I finally finished what was described to me as a "masterpiece". While it is definitely a good read, it had a few glaring flaws that need to be addressed.

1) Unlikable characters. There are a few, but there is one constant character who I wouldn't think twice about locking in a trunk which I would then proceed to drop-kick down a flight of stairs into a vat of acid.

2) Archetypal heroines. This one is less of an issue, given the medium, however it really did feel like the author was just going through a checklist of sorts, particularly the side characters.

3) Wasted plot potential/deus ex machina. This was present throughout a lot of the routes, but none more so than the Mizuha route. Seriously, I finished that route and was extremely dissapointed. The book seems to hint and foreshadow at one hell of a plot, then ignores it and either timeskips or pulls some random BS that violates Knox's Decalougue seven ways from Sunday.

All of this said, I thouroughly enjoyed the game, and find it well worth the price. I did splurge and pick up the voice pack, and recommend such to all who would read this one. I also particularly enjoyed the soundtrack, specifically the arrangements of "O Fortuna" really set the tone perfectly.

19681675.review:
TLDR: Fantastic cat-and-mouse detective story presented as a visual novel.

At first glance I thought this was just another dating simulator, but all the Steam reviews said it wasn't. And I'm glad I was curious enough to buy it. It's actually a really good detective visual novel. The story is akin to Death Note's - a genius detective tries to stop an evil criminal, and they engage in a cat-and-mouse game of outdoing each other.  At the time of this writing I'm near the end of Chapter 4 and found myself blown away by a plot twist I totally didn't see coming. 

A word of warning though - this is not traditional game. It's a visual novel and while there is the occasional choice you have to make, it's 99% reading. The story is broken in chapters, and each one will take a couple of hours or more to read through. Along the way you meet interesting characters, and each chapter of the novel usually focuses on a crime that affects one of them.

Luckily the reading is made bearable thanks to the pretty anime art that accompanies each character. I recommend buying the fully-voiced edition as it breathes more life to each character. The music that accompanies the game is made up of remixed classical music from Bach, Beethoven, etc and gives the game a unique touch.

Are there any flaws? Not really - just that sometimes the story digresses into parts that seem pointless. But sometimes these seemingly meaningless diversions turn out to play an important part later. ;)

19470936.review:
G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String is a brooding Visual Novel about a young man who is both a high school student and an officer in the Yakuza (Japanese mafia). It's a shame this is partly set in a high school because the rest of the story is a wonderfully dark drama of a young man who is in forced bondage to the mafia. 

This story reminds me of Death Note (a good thing) because of the clever battle of wits and the divided loyalties - except that Death Note is better and more polished. Be aware you may despise some of the characters for what they do, so you may feel repulsed by the game when forced to go through the story with them. Me, well, I found the dilemmas too interesting.

G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String is a worthy purchase when it's on sale. Note: there is no screenshot tool and apparently the sexual content has been removed.

19296893.review:
[h1]G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String Review[/h1]

[b]Personal History[/b]
I’ve been a fan of visual novels for quite a time now. It probably stemmed from my love for immersive stories and because of that, I was constantly reading as a child. Since I was kid, I was into anime and always heard of these “visual novels” but never really understood what exactly it was until I got around to reading them. I remember reading the fan translated G-senjou quite a while back and it left quite an impact on me and would lead to my eventual obsession into all things visual novel related. (I have no qualms towards pirating only because it was next to impossible to read English translated visual novels back then. But since that’s a bad excuse, I generally go out of my way to buy visual novels I’ve read before as they come onto steam to make up for pirating and also to support the work that went into making the product.) 

[b]Story[/b]
“The world is full of obvious things which nobody by any chance ever observes.” –Sherlock Holmes from [i]The Hound of the Baskerville[/i]

For this visual novel in particular, the story is heavily driven by corruption, money, and revenge. While it does have its light-hearted moments, this novel, at its core, is of the mystery - and thriller - genre and shows this through many different scenarios similar to that of Sherlock Holmes and Moriarty. The story itself begins a bit slow, but as more and more mysteries start revealing others and the main villain, “Maou”, shows up in the shadows, the story accelerates and it becomes very captivating. It was next to impossible - for me - to peel my eyes away from the computer screen; especially at moments like the previously mentioned “Sherlock Holmes and Moriarty”-esque scenes between the main characters Kyousuke, Haru -and others - and the villain Maou.

[b]Sound/Music and Voice Acting[/b]
Let me go ahead and say I’m a big fan of classical music. I’m also a big fan of Japanese pop music. (My computer and phone are filled with anime openings and endings that I listen to constantly). You can expect a lot of high paced violin and orchestral related music. Me trying to be as objective as possible, I really did think that all the music was very well done. It fit the mood of each scene and served to bring out the best in G-senjou. 

The voice acting is truly a wonderful addition. There really isn’t much else I can say about that. They really do bring out the best. Sometimes I had goosebumps at just how much of an immersive experience it was. Every single character that was voiced was spot on and made for an exponentially better read. That being said, the voice acting is an add-on for the Steam version. Personally I kind of want to punch you – or maybe drop-kick you - if you don’t buy it with voices, but I do understand that some people can’t pass up a cheaper product. 

[b]Artwork[/b]
In my opinion, I always thought the artwork was pretty good. It isn’t super godly tier artwork, but it’s very beautifully done. The characters are properly portrayed, the sprites are cute as heck, and transition and effects are very well done. I do enjoy the high resolution as compared to the fan translation though. I noticed people complaining about how the event CGs was cut due to the new aspect ratio, but I honestly didn’t even notice on my run through of the game even though I played the original version. Everything still looks amazing.

[b]Cut Scenes[/b]
Yes, a couple of H-scenes are cut. Coming from someone who's read it WITH the H-scenes, it didn't really...mess with the immersive-ness of the experience. 

[b]Personal Enjoyment[/b]
Obviously this is the only category that truly matters. Reading this way back when – I forget the actual year because I’m a forgetful person – this transformed my visual novel experience. It made me realize how amazing a well written story could be for a visual novel setting with its artwork and voice acting. To this day, it has remained a contender for my favorite visual novel of all time and that will probably remain a fact for many decades to come. 

I’m not going to numerically break down the scores for the key points of this visual novel but I will rate my personal enjoyment. 10/10, totally, 100% best visual novel ever, will read again. But in all honesty, this is truly a work of art. Perhaps even a masterpiece, at least in my subjective view. But in the end, only you can decide whether or not you want to read said visual novel.  

“There is nothing like first-hand evidence.” –Sherlock Holmes from [i]A Study in Scarlet[/i]

-Dris

This VN is a masterpiece. It has a great story, excellent art, interesting characters, a great soundtrack, and, of course, multiple endings. It will keep you entertained for a decent amount of time as well. I just finished one ending and it's taken over 20 hours already (and that was probably one of the shortest!). It's definitely worth picking up, if you're still on edge about getting it.

As for the voiced version, it's up to you whether or not to get it, but I'd definitely recommend it. I basically went broke after buying it, but I don't regret my decision in the slightest. The voice acting was fantastic. A lot of people are against it because they think it's a ripoff, but I'm not sure that they understand the licensing issues. It costs extra for them to get the voices in the game, and it's your choice whether to get the voices or not. Some other VNs are quite expensive simply because they're voiced, but here you have option to get it cheaper non-voiced version if you don't mind that. Price-wise as well, the voiced version here matches the same as some other high-quality fully-voiced VNs here on Steam, if not cheaper than others.

19161582.review:
[url=http://www.the-backlog.net/g-senjou-no-maou-the-devil-on-g-string-review/]You can find my full review here.[/url]

Disclaimer: I was provided a key by the publisher for review purposes.

G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String follows the story of 20-year-old Azai Kyousuke, the foster son of yakuza leader Azai Gonzou. Kyousuke is a slave to money, working for his foster father to pay off his father's staggering debt. When a new girl, Usami Haru, transfers to his soon, a mysterious man known only as "Maou" also appears. A stange series of events begin to unravel, including kidnapping and murder threats, in this 30+ hour crime/mystery visual novel.

The Devil on G-String is by far one of the best visual novels I've read to date. The writing is absolutely fanastic, although I did feel the endings were a bit weak. The artstyle and music are also fantastic, helping to show the scenes perfectly. Fans of the old fan translation may find issue with the fact the CG scenes were adjusted to fit the 16:9 format, but I felt the CG scenes looked amazing. There are some spelling issues within, such as Gonzou being spelled "Gonzo" once. Also, while the original version had erotic scenes, this version does not, though the lead-ins to them are still present. I didn't really feel like I was missing much with them not being there however, so they don't really seem to necessary.

This VN is more than worth the asking price. The voices do add to the experience, but for the asking price of getting the game voiceless, you're getting a fantastic deal. G-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-String is an easy recommendation from me for fans of crime/mystery stories, and for fans of visual novels in general.

18981865.review:
Don't let the cover or the name fool you. This is a story of family loyalty, revenge, crimes that cannot be forgiven, and hatred that cannot be let go. A picture of a few girls for the protagonist to pursue is as far from the focus of this story as it gets, but that's what sells the copies in the marketspace. The name itself is a reference to "Air on G-string", and an unfortunately distracting choice of name for the western market.

Story:
The writing is excellent, particularly if you're the sort who enjoys crime mysteries where the villain and protagonist clash in deadly knife fights of razor sharp wit. The girls who you are given the option of pursuing are a distraction in the most literal sense, as those story branches will detour you from the main plotline and prevent you from getting to the best material of the novel.

BGM:
The majority of the tracks are remixed classical pieces, some of which do an amazing job of setting the mood. A remix of "Marche Slave" was used as a mood piece and character theme for a mafia boss and I couldn't get enough of it.

Fin:
There's not much more to say than that. This isn't The Fruit of Grisaea. Grisaea was entertaining and had its dark moments, but at the end of the day it was a gal game. G-senjou no Maou is focused on telling you a story and takes a very novel approach in preventing the distractions that some buyers may be seeking from interfering with the story it wants to tell.

18962193.review:
Before we begin the review, the most common reason I see people brush off this game is because of it's title. To clear up the confusion, the title is [b]NOT[/b] referring to the butt floss type of underwear. It is referring to the musical instrument of the violin in reference to classical musician J.S. Bach.

[h1]G-Senjou No Maou Review[/h1]

(Score Breakdown Found at the Bottom of Review)

[b]Introduction & My Personal History With This Game:[/b]
If I recall correctly, my first experience with G-senjou no Maou was in 2011. I'll confess, I was a bad person and pirated the game, along with the fan translation patch, because I didn't have a legal way of purchasing this game at the time. I always feel terrible any time I do this for a product, especially if I turn out really liking the product. However, as with every product that I've ever acquired in this manner, I promised to myself that, if this game was ever officially localized, I would be sure to make it an immediate purchase. With that out of the way let's jump right into the review.

[b]Differences Between The Fan Translation and Official Localization:[/b]
First off, the interface is much cleaner. I don't remember every aspect of the original interface, but everything just feels "smoother". Switching between the currently open scene, transcript log, and save/load screen is very quick and doesn't seem jarring at all.
The next biggest thing to talk about is the removal of the sex scenes (H-Scenes). Personally, I prefer these scenes being removed. If you are someone who enjoys the H-scenes when playing Visual Novels (VN's), then I'm sorry to report that they are not present in this current version.
the artwork appears to have had some work done on it's sprites to make them look quite a bit better, and the new 720p resolution is awesome.
Lastly, from the 6 hours I've put into this game so far, I can safely say that I prefer this translation to the original fan translation. Sentences just seem to be structured a little bit better, and It just feels easier to read.

[b]Story:[/b]
This visual novel is a mystery story at it's core, and places the themes of money and corruption front and center. The story of G-senjou no Maou centers around our main protagonist Azai Kyousuke; a high school student who is a prodigy when it comes to making money. Being the adopted son of the big shot Yakuza (gangster) family known as the Azai, we follow him as he tries to live his double life of normal high school and the dark and twisted world of the Yakuza. When a new transfer student named Usami joins his class at school, and other characters start to slowly learn of his double life, Kyousuke will find himself in over his head well before he knows what hit him. While all this is going on, we learn of a certain character named "Maou" who is lurking in the shadows planning something huge, that will shake the very foundation of the city. Unfortunately, I cannot give further specific details on the story without delving into spoilers.
The pacing is the story's high point. It knows just how much time to spend with each expositional scene, character, and event. The level of immersion is also phenomenal. You'll find yourself absorbed into this story from beginning to end.

[b]Characters:[/b] 
The highlight of this VN is it's unique cast of characters. Azai Kyousuke (our protagonist, and player character) is as morally grey as they come without being a strict anti-hero. Learning more about his skills, and seeing how he deals with each situation is one of the biggest reasons to keep reading hour after hour.
Aizawa Eiichi (the "best bud" character) isn't anything like what you're used to seeing in most VN's. He's a slimeball through and through. While often pretending to be cute, innocent, and effeminate, his true nature is that of a very angry little man who wants to go out with (and "bow chicka wow wow") a MUCH older woman.
Each of the girls are also very well developed, especially the main girl Usami.
Usami Haru is very good at noticing when people are lying, and is incredibly socially awkward. She loves using game metaphors (especially those referencing the RPG genre).
Shiratori Mizuha knows about what Kyousuke is up to after school when he returns home. She's a constant threat to our protagonist. If she was to say something he could easily lose his comfortable  life.
Miwa Tsubaki is perhaps the most generic of the girls. She is the class representative of Kyousuke's class, and writes down absolutely [b]ANYTHING[/b] that happens during a day in her diary.
Azai Kanon is the last of the girls that Kyousuke interacts with on a daily basis. She is the adoptive sister of our protagonist, so they are not related by blood. She is an incredibly talented figure skater, who is trying to making it into the olympics. She adores her adopted brother and will often go out of her way to see him as much as she can.
The antagonists are also very good, but even mentioning their names (let alone their personalities) would be a huge spoiler. That said, just keep in mind that when they do show up, that they're going to be the highlight of the scene currently taking place.

[b]Artwork, Sprites, Transitions, and Effects:[/b]
There isn't really much to really say here. As far as all the visual effects go,  they're all top notch and show just how high the production values for this VN are. The new 720p resolution is also VERY welcome.

[b]Sound, Music, and Voice Acting:[/b]
Again there isn't much to say about the Sound effects. They are simply crisp, clear, and appropriate.
The music leans heavily towards the classical genre of music, and remixes of said classical music. This is appropriate as Kyousuke is a huge fan of classical music, especially J.S. Bach. There are some custom tracks, but they are far fewer in number than the classical songs on the soundtrack. Almost all tracks feature some kind of violin.

The voice acting in this game is top notch. All characters are voiced, [b]EXCEPT[/b] for Kyousuke himself. Whether you believe that having the japanese voice acting avaliable is worth paying double the price of the base game... well that's up to you. Personally I'd say that it is worth it, but if you'd prefer to get the game at half price; I can see why and wouldn't fault you for passing up the voices.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pwMIpszBD9Q]Back in January of 2012 I listed G-senjou no Maou as my favorite VN at the time.[/url] Although that list has changed a lot after reading the Zero Escape series and Danganronpa series, G-senjou no Maou Is still easily one of my top 3 visual novels. I can easily say that if you're a fan of visual novels, despite the high pricetag for a Steam VN, that you should buy this story asap. You definitely won't regret your purchase. Before ending this review, here's a numerical score breakdown for this visual novel, and a list of the types of people that I recommend this game to. 

[h1]Score Breakdown[/h1]
[b][u]User Interface:[/u][/b] 
[i]95/100 (Super Easy to Use, Smooth, and Intuitive)[/i]

[b][u]Optimization:[/u][/b] 
[i]100/100 (Will Run on a Toaster)[/i]

[b][u]Story:[/u][/b] 
[i]97/100 (Unforgettable and Amazingly Paced)[/i]

[b][u]Characters:[/u][/b] 
[i]95/100 (Unique and Memorable)[/i]

[b][u]Artwork and Visual Effects:[/u][/b] 
[i]82/100 (Solid but Slightly Dated From Being 7 Years Old)[/i]

[b][u]Sound Effects, Music, and Voice Acting:[/u][/b] 
[i]87/100 (Appropriate and Consistent)[/i]

[b][u]Overall Final Score:[/u][/b] 
[i]96/100 (Characters and Story Weighted Higher Than Other Sections)[/i]

[b][u]Recommended Purchase For Those Who Enjoy:[/u][/b] 
[i]Mystery Stories, Unique Characters, Philosophy, Criminal Underworld Stories, Drama, and/or Anime[/i]

Thank you for taking the time to read this review, and I hope it was helpful to you.

Love
[i]-Aristile[/i]

当时AKABEiSOFT2开启这个项目的时候，由于遇到种种困难，从07年开始3度跳票，剧本修改了很多次，最终塑成了这部最终成品。（当然，还有一些传闻和画师 有叶 相关） 本作荣获08年Game Award最佳剧本，最佳画面，最受玩家支持，最佳主题曲等奖项，宣称为“賭上性命的、純愛”（命をかけた、純愛）
虽然很多批判家称这部作品在剧本上巧合过多，我也承认，但是在单纯的情节上，快慢非常合适，故事紧凑，每个角色都有一个非常不错的结局。
后来在我参加的一些同人剧本创作中，G弦对我的风格影响很大，那就是诡异性叙述，到现在为止我都非常喜欢使用这个手法。
在音乐上，几乎全是一些经典古典曲目的现代复刻，可以理解为古典音乐二次创作吗？（233   后来终于有机会购入了这套OST，现在仍然躺在我的书架上。
希望大家能够enjoy这部作品.

18906390.review:
G-senjou no Maou – The devil on G-String is a mystery-thriller visual novel is developed by AKABEiSoft2 and published by Sekai Project and was released on November 5, 2015 on the Steam platform. Originally released in 2008, the Steam Release of G-senjou no Maou – The Devil on G-String marks AKABEisoft2’s first officially localized release. The Devil on G-String prices at $19.99 for the standard edition of the game, and $39.99 for a fully-voiced (in Japanese) version of the game. Both versions of the game will be discounted 30% until November 12.

[h1]The Story [/h1]
You will play as Azai Kyousuke, the adoptive son of a yakuza boss you will see the world through his eyes as he puts up a facade of being a “rich person with taste” to keep his classmates away from him. He often enjoys listening to Bach and “working” part time for his stepfather. But when a beautiful girl named Usami Haru appears in town along with an international criminal known as “Maou,” they bring with them their cat-and-mouse game of plotting and intrigue.

[h1]Visual and Music elements [/h1]
[b]Visual Elements[/b]
Backgrounds and CGs are beautiful and detailed very well done overall very smooth looking sprites and they look really cute when i first saw Miwa Tsubaki sprite with the cute “Ahoge” above her head my first impression was “wow she looks really cute”. There is also time based character color calibration which is a really cool addition because it makes the character have Evening and Night color immersion which adds to the overall atmosphere of the visual novel.

[b]Music[/b] in the menu give that creepy feeling when you play in the dark I loved the overall creepy atmosphere it manages to set and I loved the way they can turn the creepy and dark atmosphere into a cheery and cute atmosphere all with the use of music that goes along with the gloomy and bright colors being put to use. Overall music being used in the game is good

[h1]Interface and Features[/h1]
They have features like having song titles appearing at at the top right of the screen when a new song plays with the composer name.
They also have the feature to change specific characters text colors which not many Visual Novel have this feature which I find this a nice feature to have because sometimes the words colors may blend into the background and thus making it very hard to read them.

[h1]To sum up [/h1]
I would definitely recommend this visual novel to anyone because this visual novel overall would appeal to most people and would recommend anyone that likes mystery/thriller genre with investigations going on all around in the visual novel.

[url=https://azusantiara.wordpress.com/2015/11/06/g-senjou-no-maou-the-devil-on-g-string-review/]Click here for the full review![/url]
