18904298.review:
[h1][b]Warning:[/b] Terrible formatting ahead[/h1]

This is one of my favorite visual novels. Top 5 for sure. 
A lot of visual novels start off slow, making you used to the characters before you get to choose which one you want to know more about further. This can make early reading a chore for people who just want to read a story and find it difficult to make an emotional connection with each character through hours of comedy.

This novel is [u][b]not like that at all.[/b][/u] This novel starts off strong, and makes you come back because you want to know more. It grabs your curiousity, and pulls you in. This is the first and only novel I've read that does this. Not once did I feel like I had to struggle through content I didn't care about in order to get to the main dish. It's full tension from start to finish.

Unlike some visual novels, this one is very linearly story-oriented. However, there are plenty of choices to be made here. 
There are route branches to different heroines, but doing so will abandon the main story, or canon route if you want to call it that, and grant you a character-specific route. While I'm not personally into that, more power to the people who are. That's a good thing, right?

[b]Story:[/b]
The story gives me a slight Death Note vibe due to the cat and mouse battle between wits, while still being original and not copying. This is, in my opinion, a must read for people who are into that genre, and I would recommend it to anyone who likes Death Note or anything mystery/crime. 
There are a lot of dark themes, and it's definitely not a fanfare title for sure. If you prefer titles like Sakura <insert whatever here> or NekoPara, this is probably not for you. May contain badassery.

[b]Artwork:[/b]
The artwork is fairly decent, better than average to most standards. Steam's release had a lot of UI improvements made, which I only welcome. There is plenty of CG to be unlocked, and it looks pretty. 
Compared to Akabei Soft2's previous releases, it's definitely an improvement.

[b]Soundtrack:[/b]
Befitting to the title of the novel, the soundtrack consists of remixes of [u]classical music[/u]. Need I say more? There's a wide variety of classical composers, ranging from Beethoven to Bach to Tchaikovsky and the list goes on. As a Norwegian, it makes me feel special that there's even Edvard Grieg in here. Hot daym. 
And yes, the title theme is Air on G-String. No more G-string jokes pls.

[b]A few last words:[/b]
A complaint I see is the price difference between the voiced and the unvoiced version, but this is because of how Japanese voice licensing works. It's expensive, and you're given a choice, rather than being forced to pay full price. How some people see this as a negative thing confuses me.

18904041.review:
Pues ya he jugado unas horas a este juego y me esta sorprendiendo gratamente, me pensaba que era una VN como las demás (o por lo menos como muchas de las que había jugado) pero me ha resultado bastante adulta y con historia muy interesante, sin ser un bestseller, esta novela visual en la que rara vez nos preguntan algo, nos llevará a un mundo donde el prota quiere parecer un chico normal y algo alocado en la escuela, pero que en realidad es alguien importante en la compañía de su padrastro, el cual es el cabeza de una organización yakuza que controla partes de la ciudad. 

Todo parece ser normal hasta que suceden varias cosas, entre ellas una misteriosa chica que llega a mitad de curso y que al conocerla parece que está mal de la cabeza XD, en serio que las conversaciones con ella son brutales jajajaja, bueno con ella y con los demás personajes, ya que siempre te salen con unas cosas.... Diría con las pocas horas de juego que llevo, que esta visual novel se centra en como es la gente de verdad, es decir, como es con la gente en la que confía y como es con los demás, algo de lo que nos daremos cuenta nada más empezar el juego. Poco más puedo decir de la historia, pues seria destrozaros el juego y empezarlo a leer es muy interesante y entretenido, aunque me costó un poco arrancar a mi...


No todo son cosas buenas para el juego, si tuviera que decir algo negativo serían dos puntos importantes, lo primero es que si queremos escuchar las voces en japones tendremos que pagar un extra de 17 euros (19,99 si se paga por separado) algo que en mi caso no he acabado de entender, ya que encarece el producto un huevo por las voces, el otro punto negativo son los escenarios, siempre vacíos y sin vida, aunque muy bien dibujados y localizados.

El juego se nos presenta con un diseño muy propio y bien definido, el dibujo de los personajes me ha gustado bastante (aunque el padrastro podría estar mejor), las voces (si habéis pagado por ellas) son muy buenas, todo aquel que disfrute los juegos en su versión original japonesa las disfrutará, son muy profesionales y agradables de escuchar hasta el momento. La verdad es que no soy un profesional en cuanto a VN y he jugado las gustas, así que no os puedo decir si son de alguien famoso, ya que todo lo que pongo en la review es de lo que he jugado y se, no he leído nada del juego salvo un par de opiniones positivas.

Me ha sorprendido que el juego tiene 50 mil slots para guardar la partida y un huevo de opciones que aun no he ni mirado, de verdad que son muchas, incluso estilo color de subtitulos por personaje, posición, rapidez, etc.... pero lo mas sorprendente es que podéis controlar las voces por separado, callando a quien no queráis escuchar o bajándole el volumen de la voz, todo ello de manera individual. Me dejo muchas opciones, pero ya las veréis, que son muchas y ni me acuerdo XD.

Resumiendo (que poco se puede decir de una VN jugablemente), un juego que apunta maneras y que me esta gustando desde el principio, me mantiene en vilo con algunas cosas y tengo ganas de seguir, sin duda alguna cuando lo acabe os diré que me ha parecido, espero que no pegue un bajón y me deje con el culo roto, que ya me ha pasado con alguno y da mucha rabia, pero de momento no parece el caso. Espero que mi pequeña review (aun sin terminar el juego) le sirva a alguien.

18896208.review:
Short summary for newcomers follows. For information pertaining to this specific release, see below the line.

This novel game is a mystery-thriller with an unreliable narrator--the combination of which is unbelievably engrossing. The title is actually a reference to Goethe's/Schubert's "Erlkoenig" (called Maou = devil in Japan) and Bach's "Air on the G-String"--no funny business, don't get the wrong idea. Obviously, classical music plays a major role in both the musical and story motifs revisited throughout the game.

Every chapter, there is a pending crime of escalating severity that the protagonists attempt to prevent, but the antagonist stays two steps ahead of them all along the way.
----------------------
This game is near and dear to my heart, as you might garner from my screen name--I was the editor of the English fan translation. This is what I think about the Sekai Project update, cut down to bullets so you can spend more time reading the game itself.
 
-Everything's at significantly higher resolution. There's a 2000 pixel tall Gonzou sprite, for crying out loud. 2K Gonzou. Think about it. "Marche Slave" never looked and sounded more menacing. The music is still a high point, but the richly colored, HD visuals are now a fitting complement.

-Because of the new aspect ratio and higher resolution, you see a bit more of the sprites (they're actually full-body, though you could never tell in the original release) and a lot more of the backgrounds. The event cgs are cropped just a little bit, but I went through every last one, and they all still look great--better, actually, at the higher resolution.

-The new UI is much sleeker and more modern.

-The translation is awesome, duh.

-The spirit of the game isn't "censored" by any means. Literally the only parts taken out of the adults-only source material are the adults-only bits. Anything that would be rated "R" in a modern theater is still in there, last I saw... expect the gritty and dark world the 2008 Japanese release had, and nothing less.

This is exactly the build I would release as an "Editor's Cut" if I had the balls and resources of Sekai Project. Well, except I might add an Eiichi yaoi route. I love that guy. Steamworks modders, get on it.

EDIT FOR CLARITY: The game still has mature content, and even explicit sex. It's just not AS explicit. (For example, there might be a black screen while the main character directs a sex act, but then instead of showing and narrating the act "to completion", the scene cuts away.)

39270006.review:
I played this up to chapter three before finally giving it up. This is an incredibly poorly written story. I have played enough of the game that regardless of any sudden improvement that may otherwise await me, it doesn't change that what substantial amount I have played has been of mediocre quality. The characters are moronic, and their behaviour dictated by the requirements of the story. For example, the antagonist is portrayed to be extraordinarily good at their work, seemingly taking great effort to perform a crime without leaving evidence or risking capture. But those established facts about the character are entirely forgotten soon after, as they later repeatedly visit the same highly public area where they performed the initial crime, to talk to their victim. 

The main character is the worst part of the game. The main point of telling a story from someone's perspective is to get their point of view, but the writer makes it so absurdly blatant that they want you to doubt the veracity of their perspective, that to call the writer's attempt to do this simply clumsy would be a massive understatement. Not only does this detract from the experience by having the writer beat you over the head repeatedly with so much obvious foreshadowing, which may or may not be a red herring (at this point I don't care), but it gives the reader no obvious character to empathise with. What you are then left with is a main character you feel that you know nothing about, whose internal dialogue you can't even trust to be true. Whilst this is probably the intention of the writer, it doesn't lead to engaging storytelling. He's no Walter White or Michael Corleone; unlike those characters he detests the virtues of others and revels in seeing everything and everyone as a means to more wealth. The other main character, Haru isn't much better. The reader is given so little information about them that they are simply stuck as a mysterious archetypal character with no clue about her motives. 

The tone is all over the place, so that whilst covering major traumatic events that affect the characters, it punctuates them with drawn out, unfunny jokes that feel entirely unsuited to the situation. This happens repeatedly and detracts from any dramatic tension. 

The other issue I have is with the lack of mystery in how it sets up its scenarios. At one point the antagonist hides something away that the main set of characters seek to find. The writer tells and shows us exactly how and where this thing was hidden from the antagonist's perspective, and shows us that that it is intact. Then for the next large chunk of text, we are told how the main characters follow the various clues to pinpoint where the thing might be hidden, with an implied threat that it may be damaged or destroyed. There is a distinct lack of tension or mystery in that time because the reader already knows how and where the thing is hidden, and that it is in fact safe. It is just another one of the many odd ways in which the writer sabotages any dramatic tension. 

Visually it looks alright, with high definition, if slightly bland artwork. It doesn't do anything special visually, and the visual designs are typical. The music is a mixed bag with some tracks that just don't work, which was surprising as the name of the game and the way the game always tells you which track is playing leads one to think that it might include some better music. I think the decision to have the music be rearrangements of classical music sounds good on paper, but given how well known most of the music is and how many arrangements already exist the end result is lacking. 

Due to the poor writing that failed to hold my attention, I can't recommend this game.
